ArchaeologicalElement.name: Context
ArchaeologicalElement.description: The physical result of any single action whether it leaves a positive or negative record within the stratigraphic sequence. (MoLAS 1994)

property.name: Site Code
property.description: Short code to signify the excavation site and often the year of excavation.

property.name: Context ID
property.description: Every deposit or event defined is given an individual context code. Context codes are 3 letter codes. Each trench is designated with a separate letter, so it is immediately obvious whether a context belongs to a particular trench. For trench A the first context would be AAA, the second AAB and so on to AAZ. The next context was ABA and so on. It is possible to assign batches of codes to related sets of distinct contexts. For example at Boncuklu burial contexts will always have a Z as the first letter. Thus ZAA etc. Remember to fill out the context register each time you start a new context and when you complete one.

property.description: The type of compaction of sediments in the deposit eg 'Compact' 'Cemented' or 'Loose'.

lookup.term: {2.Friable} Deposit disintegrates into small particles under pressure.
{3.Crumbly} Deposit disintegrates into lumps under pressure.

property.name: Soil Texture Helper
property.description: This helper is based on the standard flow chart for determining soil texture.

property.name: Soil Texture
property.description: The type of sediment, eg clay, silt, sand and loam. Use the {Texture_Helper} or a Soil Sediment diagram for assisance.

lookup.term: {0No_Observation} No Observation. Use the Texture helper to prefil this.
{1.Sand} A sand has a loose gritty feel and does not stick together. Individual sand grains can be seen or felt. (VDEPI 2009: AG0058)
{1.Loamy_Sand} In a loamy sand particles barely stick together and a moulded piece of soil just holds its shape. (VDEPI 2009: AG0058)
{2.Silty_Clay_Loam} A silty clay loam is like a clay loam but silty as well and smooth to the touch. (VDEPI 2009: AG0058)

{2.Clay_Loam} More easily moulded into a shape than a loam a clay loam rolls out to a thin ribbon between the palms while a loam will break-up. When dry a clay loam will form a lump but is not as tough to break as a clay.(VDEPI 2009: AG0058)
{2.Sandy_Clay_Loam} A sandy clay loam is like a clay loam but sand grains can be felt (and heard - see Sandy Loam) (VDEPI 2009: AG0058)

{2.Silt_Loam} A silty loam is like a loam but has a smooth silky feel when a moist sample is pushed between the index finger and thumb. On drying a sample can form a hard lump but this may be broken by hand. (VDEPI 2009: AG0058)

{2.Loam} A loam breaks into crumbs but will tend to stick together. Sand grains cannot be felt in a moist sample which when squeezed will retain its shape when handled freely. Loams are usually soft to the feel. (VDEPI 2009: AG0058)

{2.Sandy_Loam} A sandy loam sticks together more than a loamy sand but can be easily broken. Individual sand grains can be felt and heard if a wet sample is rubbed between the index finger and thumb and held close to the ear. (VDEPI 2009: AG0058)
{3.Silty_Clay} A silty clay is like a clay but smoother. (VDEPI 2009: AG0058)

{3.Clay} Clays are tough and can be moulded into shapes when moist. Clays form a long flexible ribbon when rubbed between the palms and the ribbon can often be bent into a U shape without breaking. Clays dry into very hard clods. (VDEPI 2009: AG0058)
{3.Sandy_Clay} A sandy clay is like a clay but sand grains can be felt (and heard - see Sandy Loam). (VDEPI 2009: AG0058)

property.name: Soil Particle Sorting
property.description: Assessment of the frequency with which particles of the same size occur.

lookup.term: {3.Moderately_sorted} Particles are mostly the same size and evenly distributed but there are some larger particles.
{2.Poorly_sorted} Particles are different sizes and unevenly distributed.
{1.Very_poorly_sorted} Particles are very different sizes and very unevenly distributed.
{4.Well_sorted} Particles are roughly the same size and evenly distributed.

property.name: Soil Colour

property.name: Sterile
property.description: Whether or not the deposit is sterile, ie contains no artefacts

property.name: Deposit Inclusions
property.description: Brief description of inclusions (eg stone flecks artefacts).

property.name: Volume
property.description: All soil will be collected in buckets of a known volume – therefore a tally should be kept of buckets produced from a context and the total worked out from there.

property.name: Contamination
property.description: The extent to which the context has been contaminated.

lookup.term: {5.Contaminated} Contaminated by later material eg by unidentified cut at time of initial excavation by large scale animal or root activity which were not isolated by excavation by excavation processes some annoying person mixed the material or stuff fell into deposit from the section.

{4.High_Likely_Contaminated} It is very likely that significant amounts of earlier artifact and ecofact material has become incorporated in the deposit. For example; is this context a mud brick wall or other structure or building or structural debris or a deposit which has seen the redeposition of material excavated from cuts. These are all situations in which earlier material is likely to have been dug up and re-used (in the mud brick) or re-deposited (when digging out pits).
{2.Low_Likely_Contaminated} You think there is little chance that very much earlier material has made it's way into this deposit.

{1.Primary_Deposit} You are very sure that the deposit and all finds therein directly relate to activity within a specific period of time and there is thus minimal amounts of derived material and no contamination.

property.name: Horizon Boundary
property.description: Boundary to the next horizon

lookup.term: {Doubtful}You are uncertain of whether you accurately excavated a boundary between deposits.
{Ambiguous}You are uncertain as to whether there was a boundary between contexts.

property.name: Shape of Cut
property.description: Describe, the shape at the top i.e. circular, ovoid, square, rectangular, linear or irregular.

lookup.term: {Linear} Straight sided but not square or rectangular.
{Rectangular} Two sides longer than the other.

property.name: Shape of Corners

property.name: Break of Slope - Top

lookup.term: {Not_perceptible} Well-rounded; there is no perceptible difference between the sides of the cut and the surface into which it protrudes.

property.name: Sides of Cut
property.description: You need to describe the steepness and shape of the cut and indicate the break of slope at the top and bottom.

property.name: Shape of Base

property.name: Cut Function

property.name: Orientation

property.name: Inclination of axis

property.name: Truncation

property.name: Structure Your Interpretation
property.description: Your Interpretation of the likely functional zone of the context whether inside a structure or part of the structure itself.

property.name: Cut Your Interpretation
property.description: Your Interpretation of the likely functional zone of the context whether inside a structure or part of the structure itself.

property.name: Deposit Your Interpretation
property.description: Your Interpretation of the likely functional zone of the context whether inside a structure or part of the structure itself.

lookup.term: {Packing} Packing in a post hole for post material fulfilling a constructional purpose other than deliberate levelling deposits.
{Levelling_Fill} Material laid down to level or raise an area for constructional purposes or other activities.
{Dump} Material probably dumped as a result of other activity e.g. material removed from cuts or other constructional or destructional activity.
{Midden} Distinct area of organic rubbish accumulation

{Partly_naturally_derived} Some of the deposit accumulating through the deposition of natural sediments through geomorphological processes eg wind borne sediments water-laid natural sediments material flaking from cave and rock shelter walls.

{Wholly_naturally_derived} All of the deposit accumulating through the deposition of natural sediments through geomorphological processes eg wind borne sediments water-laid natural sediments material flaking from cave and rock shelter walls.
{Erosional_products} Material deriving from the erosion of earlier archaeological sediments.
{Artifact_cluster} A distinct concentration of artifacts or ecofacts. Make sure you record its xyz coordinates centre and edges.

{Arbitrary} This applies to artificial contexts excavated for excavational convenience eg section cleaning material whose precise provenience is unclear. Does not include arbitrary spits or spatial units deliberately excavated for finer control of horizontal and vert

{Distinct_floor_contact} To be used for material that directly reflects the use of a surface or floor – artifact material on the surface perhaps thin deposits of occupation material. These contexts will be gridded into spatial units for closer control of artifact distributions.
{Animal_or_Plant} Deposit derived from plant or animal activity

property.description: An appropriate mid-point on the skeleton under excavation should be recorded on the X / Y co-ordinates. This will locate the skeleton on the site grid system.

property.name: Mid_Y
property.description: An appropriate mid-point on the skeleton under excavation should be recorded on the X / Y co-ordinates. This will locate the skeleton on the site grid system.

property.name: Skeleton Dimensions
property.description: Record the approximate extent of the skeletal remains (in meters or millimetres only) and the axis of measurement. Detailed dimensions can be taken from the plan.

property.name: Skeleton Body
property.description: Describe the attitude of the body, whether it is extended, crouched, flexed, supine (front up), prone (face down) and the orientation.

property.name: Skeleton Head
property.description: Which way up the head faces and/or points

property.name: Skeleton Right Arm
property.description: Record whether right arm is straight or flexed, is along the side of the body, over the chest or on the pelvis, and the position of the hand.

property.name: Skeleton Left Arm
property.description: Record whether left arm is straight or flexed, is along the side of the body, over the chest or on the pelvis, and the position of the hand.

property.name: Skeleton Right Leg
property.description: Record whether the leg is straight or bent, crossed left over right or right over left and the position of the foot

property.name: Skeleton Left Leg
property.description: Record whether the leg is straight or bent, crossed left over right or right over left and the position of the foot

property.name: Skeleton Condition
property.description: Describe the general condition of the skeleton and any comments on articulation. Any degeneration of bone in situ is important to record as well as accidental damage during excavation and lifting. Record disturbances through later activity or animal/root activity as well as damage due to stone pressure on the bones. It is important to note whether the patellae, hyoid, phalanges, basi-occipital etc are present or not, and their location, as this may give an indication of the state of the body at the time of interment.

property.name: Skeleton Surface Modifications
property.description: Note any cut marks, evidence of stains and/or colour during the course of the excavation, burning, chewing marks, root activity etc.

property.name: Skeleton Environment
property.description: The physical environment at the time of excavation may affect the state of the bone therefore it is important to note the weather and conditions you are working in.

property.name: Skeleton Days Exposed
property.description: It is important to excavate skeletal remains as quickly as possible as the state of the bone will change during exposure. Any conditional change should also be noted. Excavate as quickly as possible because the bones will degrade rapidly.
